title: 111_hr6207
content: The "Rural Flood Mitigation and Recovery Act of 2010" allows the Secretary of the Army to recommend flood damage reduction projects in disaster areas based on the non-Federal interest's demonstration of the project's necessity for long-term economic viability. The term "flood prone disaster area" is defined as an area designated by the President under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. SEC. 428 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act designates flood prone disaster areas. The President determines flood prone disaster areas based on criteria such as experiencing at least 2 other major disasters due to flooding in the previous 5 years. This designation applies to assistance provided under the Act for that disaster. Special rules apply for contributions towards hazard mitigation measures in these areas. The President may increase federal funding for hazard mitigation measures in flood-prone disaster areas to 90% or 100% if necessary for long-term economic viability. Contributions for these measures will be increased to 20% and 25% respectively. The President can increase federal funding for hazard mitigation in flood-prone disaster areas to 90% or 100% for long-term economic viability. A task force is established in each State with a flood-prone disaster area to coordinate response activities appropriately. Each task force in flood-prone disaster areas should be composed of relevant Federal and State agency heads for effective coordination of response activities. SEC. 4. HAZARD MITIGATION. Amends Section 404 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to specify timing requirements for contributions to hazard mitigation measures after a major disaster. SEC. 5. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS AND HOUSEHOLDS. SEC. 5. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS AND HOUSEHOLDS. Amends Section 408(a) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to consider economic impact and previous disasters when providing assistance to individuals or households affected by a major disaster. SEC. 6. EMERGENCY RELIEF. Amends Section 120(e) of title 23, United States Code, to allow for delays in relief efforts due to inclement weather or flooding. SEC. 7. REPAIR, RESTORATION, AND REPLACEMENT OF DAMAGED FACILITIES PILOT PROGRAM. During a 2-year period, the President will select 3 major disasters for modified response procedures. This involves making contributions for repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement projects based on selected bids. A report on the benefits of these procedures must be submitted to Congress within 30 months of enactment. The President will select 3 major disasters for modified response procedures, involving contributions for projects based on bids. A report on benefits and overpayments must be submitted to Congress within 30 months of enactment. SEC. 8. INDIAN TRIBE DISASTER RESPONSE MANAGEMENT PILOT PROGRAM. The President shall establish an Indian tribe disaster response management pilot program, selecting 5 Indian tribes based on past major disaster declarations. Selected tribes will be treated as states for participation in the program. The President shall establish an Indian tribe disaster response management pilot program, selecting 5 Indian tribes based on past major disaster declarations. Selected tribes will be treated as states for participation in the program. An Indian tribe selected for participation in the program shall be treated as a State for requesting a declaration of a major disaster and managing response activities. The President is authorized to provide technical assistance and grants to ensure the tribe is prepared for disaster response activities. The President will submit a report to Congress 30 months after enacting the Act, detailing the program's results and recommendations, including whether to make the program permanent for all Indian tribes. SEC. 9 authorizes FEMA to grant states for road project studies and implementation plans for disaster preparedness. SEC. 10 requires a report on improving communication between FEMA and state/local officials. SEC. 11 mandates a report on hazard mitigation assistance. SEC. 11 of the Act requires the President to submit a report to Congress within 6 months, detailing the use of contributions for hazard mitigation projects and assessing their effectiveness. Recommendations for improvement and the interaction with contributions for hazard mitigation measures are also included. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the effectiveness of disaster relief processes under the Stafford Act in assisting distressed communities, including Indian tribes. A report will be submitted to Congress within 12 months. Additionally, a study will be conducted on the paperwork reduction for hazard mitigation projects under the Stafford Act. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 12 months on the effectiveness of disaster relief processes and recommendations for streamlining application processes for hazard mitigation activities.
